front.title: ACVP RSA Algorithm Validation JSON Specification

author.organization: National Institute of Standards and Technology

abstract.t: This document defines the JSON schema for testing RSA algorithm and component implementations for conformance to and with the ACVP specification.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Automated Crypto Validation Protocol (ACVP) defines a mechanism to automatically verify the cryptographic implementation of a software or hardware crypto module. The ACVP specification defines how a crypto module communicates with an ACVP server, including crypto capabilities negotiation, session management, authentication, vector processing and more. The ACVP specification does not define algorithm specific JSON constructs for performing the crypto validation. A series of ACVP sub-specifications define the constructs for testing individual crypto algorithms. Each sub-specification addresses a specific class of crypto algorithms. This sub-specification defines the JSON constructs for testing RSA algorithm and component implementations for conformance to and using ACVP.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted in RFC 2119.

section.title: Testing scope
section.t: The ACVP testing for RSA allows conformance testing for all modes of using the algorithm as specified in : key generation, signature generation, signature verification, and component primitives. ACVP testing for RSA also allows conformance testing for : decryption primitives. Correspondingly, ACVP allows testing of the five different methods for key generation in , Appendix B.3.

section.title: Capabilities Registration
section.t: ACVP requires cryptographic modules to register their capabilities. This allows the cryptographic module to advertise support for specific algorithms and their modes, notifying the ACVP server which algorithms need test vectors generated for the validation process. This section describes the constructs for advertising support of the RSA algorithm in all allowed modes to the ACVP server - see for details.

section.title: Supported RSA Algorithm modes
section.t: The following RSA algorithm modes may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

texttable.title: Supported RSA Algorithm Modes JSON Values

section.title: Required Prerequisite Algorithms for RSA Mode Validations
section.t: Each RSA Mode implementation relies on other cryptographic primitives (algorithms) - see . For example, a keyGen implementation uses underlying DRBG and hash algorithms. In some cases, a single RSA Mode implementation may use several primitives of the same type. For example, two different DRBG implementations may be used in the keyGen algorithms in Appendix B.3.3 in , one in step 4.2 and another in step 5.2. Each of these underlying algorithm primitives must be validated, either separately or as part of the same submission. ACVP provides a mechanism for specifying the required prerequisites:

texttable.title: Required RSA Modes Prerequisite Algorithms JSON Values
texttable.c: object with algorithm and valValue properties

section.title: Supported RSA Capabilities
section.t: The algorithm capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within the 'algorithms' value of the ACVP registration message. The 'algorithms' value is an array, where each array element is an individual JSON object defined in this section. The 'algorithms' value is part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each RSA algorithm capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object. The following JSON values are used for RSA algorithm capabilities:

texttable.title: RSA Algorithm Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: The RSA algorithm to be validated
The RSA algorithm mode to be validated
array of JSON objects, each with fields pertaining to the global RSA mode indicated above and identified uniquely by the combination of the RSA "mode" and indicated properties

section.title: Supported RSA Modes Capabilities
section.t: The RSA mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within the 'algSpecs' value of the ACVP registration message - see . The 'algSpecs' value is an array, where each array element is a JSON object corresponding to a particular RSA mode defined in this section. The 'algSpecs' value is part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each RSA mode's capabilities are advertised as JSON objects.

section.title: The keyGen Mode Capabilities
section.t: The RSA keyGen mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects, which are elements of the 'algSpecs' array in the ACVP registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each RSA keyGen mode capability set is advertised as a self-contained JSON object.
The following subsections define the capabilities that may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto modules.

section.title: keyGen Full Set Of Capabilities
section.t: The complete list of RSA key generation capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

texttable.title: RSA keyGen Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: This flag indicates that the server is responsible for generating inputs for Key Generation tests. This flag is not relevant to KeyGen mode "B.3.3" Random Probable Primes
Supports fixed or random public key exponent e
The value of the public key exponent e in hex if pubExpMode is "fixed"

The preferred private key format. The "standard" format has "p", "q", and "d" as the components of the private key. The "crt" (Chinese Remainder Theorem) format has "p", "q", "dmp1" (d modulo p-1), "dmq1" (d modulo q-1), and "iqmp" (inverse q modulo p) as the components.
An array of objects containing capabilities for all supported moduli, primality test, and hash algorithms for a single key generation mode
supported RSA modulo for the randPQ mode - see , Appendix B.3
Supported hash algorithms for the randPQ mode - see , Appendix B.3
Yes, applicable for randPQ B.3.2, B.3.4, B.3.5
Primality test rounds of Miller-Rabin from Table C.2 or Table C.3 in , Appendix C.3
Yes, applicable for randPQ B.3.3, B.3.5, B.3.6

section.title: The sigGen Mode Capabilities
section.t: The RSA sigGen mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within the 'algSpecs' array as part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.

Each RSA sigGen mode capability is advertised as a self-contained JSON object consisting of the algorithm, mode, and algSpecs array. The algSpecs array may contain multiple elements, each pertaining to a sigType that is supported by the client for the RSA mode being advertised.
The following subsections define the capabilities that may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto modules.

section.title: sigGen Capabilities
section.t: The following RSA signature generation capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

texttable.title: Supported RSA sigGen moduli and hash options JSON Values
texttable.c: supported RSA signature types - see , Section 5
capabilites supported for this sigType - see , Section 5
a single modulo with an array of at least one hashPair
supported RSA moduli for signature generation - see , Section 5
one of the supported modulo sizes {2048, 3072, 4096}
supported hash algorithms and optional salt length for signature generation for this sigType and modulo - see , Section 9
an array of objects containing a hashAlg and an optional saltLen
supported hash algorithm for signature generation for this sigType and modulo - see , Section 9
supported salt lengths in bytes for PSS signature generation - see , Section 5.5. See also note below.
any integer value subject to the constraint in the note below.

section.t: Note: the salt length for each hash algorithm used in PSS signature generation is between 0 and the length of the corresponding hash function output block (in bytes), the end points included.

section.title: The sigVer Mode Capabilities
section.t: The RSA sigVer mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within the array of 'algSpecs' as part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.

Each RSA sigVer mode capability is advertised as a self-contained JSON object consisting of the algorithm, mode, and algSpecs array. The algSpecs array may contain multiple elements, each pertaining to a sigType that is supported by the client for the RSA mode being advertised.
The following subsections define the capabilities that may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto modules.

section.title: sigVer Capabilities
section.t: The following RSA signature verification capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

texttable.title: Supported RSA sigVer moduli and hash options JSON Values
texttable.c: supported RSA signature types - see , Section 5
capabilites supported for this sigType - see , Section 5
a single modulo with an array of at least one hashPair
supported RSA moduli for signature verification - see , Section 5
one of the supported modulo sizes {1024, 2048, 3072, 4096}
supported hash algorithms and optional salt length for signature verification for this sigType and modulo - see , Section 9
an array of objects containing a hashAlg and an optional saltLen
supported hash algorithm for signature verification for this sigType and modulo - see , Section 9
supported salt lengths in bytes for PSS signature verification - see , Section 5.5. See also note below.
any integer value subject to the constraint in the note below.
if pubExpMode is defined as "fixed", this is the corresponding public exponent value

section.t: Note: the salt length for each hash algorithm used in PSS signature generation is between 0 and the length of the corresponding hash function output block (in bytes), the end points included. The exception to this rule is using "sha2-512" with a modulo of 1024. The maximum salt length for this combination is 62 bytes instead of the expected 64 bytes.

section.title: The legacySigVer Mode Capabilities
section.t: The RSA legacySigVer mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within the array of 'algSpecs' as part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.

Each RSA legacySigVer mode capability is advertised as a self-contained JSON object consisting of the algorithm, mode, and algSpecs array. The algSpecs array may contain multiple elements, each pertaining to a sigType that is supported by the client for the RSA mode being advertised.
The following subsections define the capabilities that may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto modules.

texttable.title: Supported RSA legacySigVer moduli and hash options JSON Values
texttable.c: supported RSA legacy signature types - see , Section 5
RSA legacy signature verification parameters - see , Section 5
modulo, hashAlg, and saltLen (when sigType is "pss")
supported RSA modulo for signature verification - see , Section 5
any one of the supported modulo sizes {1024, 1536, 2048, 3072, 4096}
supported hash algorithms and optional salt length for signature verification for this sigType and modulo - see , Section 9
an array of objects containing a hashAlg and an optional saltLen
supported hash algorithms for this sigType and modulo - see , Section 9
supported salt lengths for PSS signature verification - see , Section 5.5. See also note below.
array of values for each hash algorithm used subject to the constraint in the note below.
if pubExpMode is defined as "fixed", this is the corresponding public exponent value

section.t: Note: the salt length for each hash algorithm used in PSS signature generation is between 0 and the length of the corresponding hash function output block (in bytes), the end points included.

section.title: The signaturePrimitive Mode Capabilities
section.t: The RSA signaturePrimitive mode capabilities (otherwise known as RSASP1 in ) are advertised as JSON objects within the array of 'algSpecs' as part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message. A single property is allowed in the registration. KeyFormat as described above. In this mode, the only tested capability is the correct exponentiation of 's = msg^d mod n', where 'msg' is a message between '0' and 'n - 1', 'd' is the private exponent and 'n' is the modulus, all supplied by the testing ACVP server. In the event that 'keyFormat' is defined as 'crt', then 'd' is replaced with 'dmp1', 'dmq1', and 'iqmp'. Only 2048-bit RSA keys are allowed for this capability. There are no properties specified for this capability. See for additional details on constraints for 'msg' and 'n'. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.

section.title: The decryptionPrimitive Mode Capabilities
section.t: The RSA decryptionPrimitive mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within the array of 'algSpecs' as part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. A single property is allowed in the registration, 'modulo' with the only approved value of 2048. In this mode, the only tested capability is the correct exponentiation 's = cipherText^d mod n', where 'cipherText' is a cipherText to be decrypted, 'd' is the private exponent and 'n' is the modulus. See , Section 7.1.2 for details.

In testing, only 'cipherText' is supplied by the ACVP server. The client is responsible for generating RSA key pairs of modulus 'n', private key 'd', and calculates 's'. If a client does not support decryption with a standard RSA private exponent 'd', the equivalent Chinese Remainder Theorem (CRT) private key values are allowed to be used. Only 2048-bit RSA keys are allowed for this capability. See for additional details on constraints for 'cipherText' and 'n'. The client provides the public exponent 'e', modulus 'n' and the computed result 's' in its response to the ACVP - see . The client must first check if '0 < cipherText < n-1' and return an error if this is not the case. The client returns a value 's' only when 'cipherText' is in the proper range for the size of the selected modulus 'n'. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.

section.title: Test Vectors
section.t: The ACVP server provides test vectors to the ACVP client, which are then processed by the client and returned to the ACVP server for validation. A typical ACVP validation session would require multiple test vector sets to be downloaded and processed by the ACVP client. Each test vector set represents an individual algorithm and mode, such as {"algorithm": "RSA, "mode": "sigGen"}, etc. This section describes the JSON schema for test vector sets used with the RSA algorithm and modes.

The test vector set JSON schema is a multi-level hierarchy that contains meta data for the entire vector set as well as individual test vectors to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements at the top level of the hierarchy.

texttable.title: Vector Set JSON Object
texttable.c: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
The RSA algorithm used for the test vectors.
The RSA mode used for the test vectors.
Array of test group JSON objects, which are defined in

section.title: Test Groups JSON Schema
section.t: The testGroups element at the top level in the test vector JSON object is an array of test groups. Test vectors are grouped into similar test cases to reduce the amount of data transmitted in the vector set. The Test Group JSON object contains meta data that applies to all test vectors within the group. The following table describes the RSA JSON elements of the Test Group JSON object.

texttable.title: Test Group JSON Object
texttable.c: Miller-Rabin constraint from Table C.2 or C.3
Fixed public exponent value if pubExpMode is defined as "fixed"
Type of signature used in the group
The salt length for the group in bytes

section.title: Test Case JSON Schema
section.t: Each test group contains an array of one or more test cases. Each test case is a JSON object that represents a single test vector to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each RSA test vector.

texttable.title: RSA Test Case JSON Object
texttable.c: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set.
the random for P, testing probable primes according to , Appendix B.3.3
the random for Q, if applicable, testing probable primes according to , Appendix B.3.3
the salt value used to sign the message

section.title: Test Vector Responses
section.t: After the ACVP client downloads and processes a vector set, it must send the response vectors back to the ACVP server. The following table describes the JSON object that represents a vector set response.

texttable.title: Vector Set Response JSON Object
texttable.c: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
Array of JSON objects that represent each test vector result, which uses the same JSON schema as defined in

section.t: The following table describes the JSON elements for the response to a RSA test vector.

texttable.title: RSA Test Case Results JSON Object
texttable.c: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set.
the random for P, testing probable primes according to , Appendix B.3.3
the random for Q, if applicable, testing probable primes according to , Appendix B.3.3
the verdict on the prime generation testing for the supplied pRand/qRand combination, see , Appendix B.3.3.
the verdict from the signature verification process, or the signature primitive process.
the verdict for the decryption primitive process.
the seed used in prime generation according to , Appendix B.3.2, B.3.4, or B.3.5
the length of p1, p2, q1, and q2 for prime generation according to , Appendix B.3.2, B.3.4, B.3.5 or the length of xP1, xP2, xQ1, and xQ2 for B.3.6
the prime factor p1 for Primes with Conditions - see , Appendix B.3.3, B.3.4, or B.3.5, if applicable
the prime factor p2 for Primes with Conditions - see , Appendix B.3.3, B.3.4, or B.3.5, if applicable
the random number used in Step 3 of the algorithm in , Appendix C.9 to generate the prime P, if applicable
the prime factor q1 for Primes with Conditions - see , Appendix B.3.3, B.3.4, or B.3.5, if applicable
the prime factor q2 for Primes with Conditions - see , Appendix B.3.3, B.3.4, or B.3.5, if applicable
the random number used in Step 3 of the algorithm in , Appendix C.9 to generate the prime Q, if applicable
the private exponent d modulo (p - 1) used in a Chinese Remainder Theorem private key
the private exponent d modulo (q - 1) used in a Chinese Remainder Theorem private key
the multiplicative inverse of q modulo p used in a Chinese Remainder Theorem private key

section.t: Security considerations are addressed by the ACVP specification.

section.title: Example RSA Capabilities JSON Objects
section.t: This appendix contains example JSON object advertising support for the verious RSA modes:keyGen, sigGen, sigVer, legacySigVer, compRSASP1. Note that all binary HEX representations are in big-endian format.

section.title: Example keyGen with Provable Primes and Provable Primes with Conditions Capabilities JSON Objects
section.t: The following is an example JSON object advertising support for RSA keyGen with provable primes according to , Appendix B.3.2, and provable primes with conditions according to , Appendix B.3.4. See also .

section.title: Example keyGen with Probable Primes Capabilities JSON Object
section.t: The following is an example JSON object advertising support for RSA keyGen with probable primes according to , Appendix B.3.3, as well as probably primes with conditions according to , Appendix B.3.6. See also .

section.title: Example keyGen with Provable Conditional Primes with Probable Factors Capabilities JSON Object
section.t: The following is an example JSON object advertising support for RSA keyGen with primes with conditions according to , Appendix B.3.5. See also .

section.title: Example Test Vectors JSON Objects
section.t: This appendix contains example JSON objects for test vectors sent from the ACVP server to the crypto module.

section.title: Example Test Vectors for keyGen JSON Objects
section.t: Note that this example has "infoGeneratedByServer" set to false. This means the client is responsible for providing the details by running an instance of the appropriate Key Generation method for each test. The information returned should match all applicable data in . For Key Generation method 2 (Appendix B.3.3 ) if the public exponent is random, there are two test types. One is a known answer test (KAT) provided by the server resulting in a "pass"/"fail" response determining if the input forms a valid key pair. The other, which exists for a fixed public exponent as well, asks the client to generate 10 key pairs ('e', 'p', 'q', 'n', and 'd') and the server validates that this pair matches the requirements. Below is an example set of test vectors that would come from the server when the registration includes "infoGeneratedByServer" set to true.

section.title: Example Test Vectors for keyGen when infoGeneratedByServer is true
Example Test Vectors for sigGen JSON Objects
Example Test Vectors for sigVer JSON Objects
section.t: Note: The ACVP server does retain additional context for each test vector sent to the client in order to verify the results when submitted for validation. These may include the public key n, the public exponent e, the private key d for each test. Note also that each test for which msg is not between 0 and n - 1 should fail.

section.title: Example Test Vectors for legacySigVer JSON Objects
section.t: The format and structure of legacySigVer Test Vector JSON Objects is identical to those for the Test Vectors for sigVer JSON Objects.

section.title: Example Test Vectors for signaturePrimitive JSON Objects
section.t: Note: The ACVP server does retain additional context for each test vector sent to the client in order to verify the results when submitted for validation. These may include the public key 'n', the public exponent 'e', the private key 'd' for each test. Note also that each test for which 'msg' is not between '0' and 'n - 1' should fail.

section.title: Example Test Vectors for decryptionPrimitive JSON Objects
section.t: Note: The ACVP server does retain additional context for each test vector sent to the client in order to verify the results when submitted for validation. These may include the public key 'n', the public exponent 'e', the private key 'd' for each test. Note also that each test for which 'cipherText' is not between '0' and 'n - 1' should fail.
